choices.text: Biobrane
Amniotic graft
Hydrocolloid dressings (Duoderm)
Vaseline impregnated gauze

questions.text: Identify the material attached to the burns wound in the picture below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Biobrane

 

Option A:

 

Biobrane is a biosynthetic wound dressing made of a silicone membrane and a nylon fabric partially embedded with collagen. It adheres to the wound bed of superficial burns, creating a protective barrier that facilitates the body's healing process. Because of its semi-permeable nature, it allows for the exchange of fluids and gases, which helps to maintain a moist healing environment without the need for frequent dressing changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Amniotic Graft: Amniotic grafts are derived from the amniotic membrane part of the placenta. They are used in burn care and wound management for their natural therapeutic properties, which include anti-inflammatory factors and growth-promoting effects. These grafts can reduce scar formation, pain, and healing time.

 

 

Option C. Hydrocolloid Dressings (Duoderm): 

Hydrocolloid dressings like Duoderm are made of gel-forming agents like pectin or gelatin. They provide a moist and insulated healing environment, which can help in the management of light to moderately exuding wounds. These dressings are self-adhesive and can conform to the wound site, but they need to be changed every few days.

 

 

Option D. Vaseline Impregnated Gauze: This type of dressing consists of gauze that has been saturated with petrolatum (Vaseline). It is non-adherent, which makes it a good choice for wounds with fragile skin where the dressing needs to be changed without causing trauma. It helps keep the wound moist and protected from outside contaminants.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hydrocolloid dressings need to be changed every 3–5 days. They also provide a moist environment, which is good for epithelialization.
  • Biosynthetic dressings (e.g., Bio brane®) and natural (e.g., amniotic membranes) dressings also provide good healing environments and do not need to be changed. They are ideal for one-stop management of superficial burns, being easy to apply and comfortable. However, they will become detached if applied to deep dermal wounds as the eschar needs to separate. They are therefore not as useful in mixed-depth wounds.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 672

choices.text: 4 mL/kg × % TBSA of colloids + crystalloids
4 mL/kg × %TBSA of crystalloids alone
2 mL/kg × %TBSA of colloids alone
2mL/kg × %TBSA of crystalloids and colloids

questions.text: A woman was brought to the casualty 2 hours after sustaining burns on the abdomen, both the limbs and back. What will be the formula to calculate amount of fluid to be replenished as per Parkland’s?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 mL/kg × %TBSA of crystalloids alone

 

Option B:

 

  • According to Parkland’s formula

 

 

The most common fluid used is Ringer’s lactate.

 

Others: human albumin solution or fresh-frozen plasma, and hypertonic saline can be used after 24 hours.

 

  • Only areas covered by second-degree burns or greater is taken into consideration, as first-degree bums do not cause hemodynamically significant fluid shift to warrant fluid replacement.
  • According to current ATLS (2018) guidelines, this formula has been modified to:

 

2 ml/kg X %TBSA if age > 14 years

 

3 ml/kg X %TBSA if age < 14 years

 

4 ml/kg X %TBSA for electrical burns

 

Resuscitation endpoints and monitoring:

 

  • Urine output: 0.5 mL/kg/hr urine output in adults (50—100 cc/hr) and 0.5—1.0 mL/kg/hr in children <30 kg.
  • Heart rate: HR < 110 in adults usually indicates adequate volume.
  • Narrowed pulse pressure provides an earlier indication of shock than does systolic blood pressure alone.
  • Serum lactate is a strong predictor of mortality and trends of serum lactate correlate with haemostatic status.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 671

choices.text: Scald
Fat burns
Electrical burn
Strong concentration acid burns

questions.text: Which of these burns mechanisms is unlikely to cause a deep or full thickness burn?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scald

 

Explanation

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 669, table 46.2

choices.text: First degree burn
Second degree superficial burn
Second degree deep burn
Third degree burn

questions.text: A child has scald burns on both of his hands due to hot water treatment. The lesion is pink, oozing and painful to air and touch. What is the depth?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Second degree superficial

 

Option B:


The description of the scald burns on the child's hands indicates that the lesion is pink, oozing, and painful to air and touch. The correct answer provided, B, Second degree superficial.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. First Degree: Also known as epidermal burns, these affect only the outer layer of skin, the epidermis. The skin is typically red and painful, but there is no blistering, and it does not ooze.

 

Option C. Second Degree Deep: A deeper second-degree burn affects deeper layers of the dermis and may present without pain if nerve endings are damaged. The skin may appear white or mottled and will not be as pliable.

 

Option D. Third Degree: This burn affects the full thickness of the skin, destroying both the epidermis and dermis. It can extend into the subcutaneous tissue. The area may be white, brown, or black, and it is often painless initially due to nerve destruction.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition 669-671

choices.text: All skin appendages are destroyed
Lesions are very painful and require application of anesthetic agents
Skin is white, charred, leathery and does not blanch
Contractures and scarring is seen

questions.text: Which of these statements is not true regarding third degree burns?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lesions are very painful and require application of anesthetic agents.

 

Option B:

 

Lesions are very painful and require the application of anaesthetic agents. Third-degree burns are characterized by the destruction of nerve endings. Therefore, they are often painless or have reduced sensation as nerves are damaged.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. All skin appendages are destroyed: Third-degree burns extend through the full thickness of the skin, involving the epidermis, dermis, and often the underlying structures, leading to the destruction of all skin appendages such as hair follicles, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands.

 

Option C. Skin is white, charred, leathery, and does not blanch: Third-degree burns result in a white or charred appearance, and the skin becomes leathery.

 

Option D. Contractures and scarring are seen: Third-degree burns can lead to the formation of contractures and extensive scarring (eschar) as the healing process involves the contraction of the surrounding tissue.

 

Educational objective:

 

Third-degree burns are typically painless or have reduced sensation due to nerve destruction, making the application of anesthetic agents unnecessary for pain management.

 

Third degree burns are not painful and have no sensation as nerves are destroyed.

 

BURNS

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition 669-671

choices.text: Palm method
Rule of 9
Lund and Browder chart
Berkow tables

questions.text: A 5-year-old child spills boiling water accidentally over her face and trunk. Which of the following methods is most correct to estimate the body surface area involved in burns?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lund and Browder chart

 

Option C:

 

Lund and Browder chart: This method is most appropriate for children as it considers the changing body proportions with age. The chart provides a more accurate assessment of the true burn size in children.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palm method: The patient's hand is approximately 1% of the total body surface area (TBSA) and can be used as a quick guide for small or patchy burns.

 

Option B. Rule of 9: The Wallace Rule of Nines is commonly used in adults. It divides the body into regions, each representing 9% or a multiple of 9%. This method is less accurate for children due to differences in body proportions.

 

Option D. Berkow tables: Berkow formula is used to accurately determine burn size according to age, and it provides a more individualized approach than the Rule of 9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lund and Browder chart is the preferred method for estimating burn size in children, considering their changing body proportions. This chart provides a more accurate assessment compared to the Rule of 9, especially in pediatric cases.

 

Burn Size (% BSA):

 

  • Burn size is assessed by Wallace rule of nines.
  • An infant’s head is proportionally larger than an adult’s and this adjustment is represented on the modified Lund and Browder chart for children, where at birth the head represents 18% and the lower limbs 13.5% each. For each year 1% is subtracted from the head, with 0.5% being added to each lower limb until the age of 10, when the body proportions are roughly equivalent to those of an adult.
  • For estimating smaller burns: Area of open hand (including palm and extended fingers) of the patient is approximately 1% of TBSA.

 

Wallace Rule of Nine*

 

  • In adults:
    • Each upper extremity: 9%
    • Head and neck: 9%
    • Lower extremities: 18%
    • Anterior and posterior aspects of the trunk: 18%
    • Perineum and genitalia: 1%

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition Pg 668

choices.text: Blood glucose levels
Carboxyhemoglobin level
Myoglobinuria
Peripheral pulse and circulation

questions.text: A patient suffers from a third-degree circumferential burn in the arm and forearm region. Which of the following should be monitored in these patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peripheral pulse and circulation

 

Option D:

 

Full thickness/third degree circumferential burns may lead to formation of “eschar” which exerts a tourniquet effect on the limb leading to compartment syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is important to monitor peripheral pulse and circulation in cases of circumferential burns to prevent complications associated with compromised blood flow (compartment syndrome) due to tourniquet effect by eschar.

 

  • When deep second and third-degree wounds encompass the circumference of an extremity peripheral circulation to the limb can be compromised.
  • Development of generalized edema beneath a non-yielding eschar impedes venous outflow and affects arterial inflow to the distal beds.
  • This can be recognized by numbness and tingling in the limb and increased pain in digits.
  • Circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs and torso require emergency surgery in the form of escharotomy. The tourniquet effect of this injury is treated by incising the whole length of full-thickness burns

 

 

Image shows circumferential full thickness burns on lower limb with longitudinal escharotomy.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition 673

choices.text: Binasal catheter O2 inhalation
O2 therapy with well fitting face mask
Elective cricothyroidotomy
Elective endotracheal intubation

questions.text: What would be the safest strategy of treatment for a patient of inhalational burn injury who has presented within 3-4 hours of burns?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elective endotracheal intubation

 

Option D:

 

  • The burned airway creates problems for the patient by laryngeal edema and, if not managed proactively, can completely occlude the upper airway.
  • The treatment is to secure the airway with an endotracheal tube until the swelling has subsided, which is usually after about 48 hours.
  • The time frame from burn to airway occlusion is usually between 4 and 24 hours, so there is time to make a sensible decision and allow an experienced anaesthetist to intubate the patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Binasal Catheter O2 Inhalation:

 

  • This method may provide supplemental oxygen but does not address the potential complications of airway swelling associated with inhalational burn injury.

 

Option B. O2 Therapy with Well-Fitting Face Mask:

 

  • While a well-fitting face mask can deliver oxygen, it does not ensure the protection of the compromised airway in cases of inhalational injury.
  • Inhalational burns can lead to airway edema and compromise, making definitive airway management necessary.

 

Option C. Elective Cricothyroidotomy:

 

  • Cricothyroidotomy involves creating an emergency airway through the cricothyroid membrane.
  • While it can be a life-saving procedure, elective endotracheal intubation is preferred when feasible, as it provides a more secure airway and allows for controlled ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early elective endotracheal intubation is important in inhalational burn injury to secure the airway, prevent complications, and ensure adequate ventilation within the critical timeframe of 4-5 hours.

 

Initial Management of the Burned Airway

 

  • Early elective intubation is safest
  • Delay can make intubation very difficult because of swelling
  • Be ready to perform an emergency cricothyroidotomy if intubation is delayed

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition 673

choices.text: Epidermis
Epidermis + superficial dermis
Epidermis + whole dermis
Whole skin + connective tissue, muscle, bone

questions.text: A 30-year-old housewife accidentally spilled hot tea all over herself at a kitty party. She gets this lesion which is very painful and erythematous. Which layers of the skin are affected in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidermis + superficial dermis.

 

Option B:

 

The clinical scenario points towards second degree superficial burns as lesion is painful, erythematous and blister formation is seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition 669-671

choices.text: Zone of coagulation- most severely burned portion.
Zone of hyperemia- heals with minimal scarring.
Zone of stasis – has variable degree of vasoconstriction.
Zone of coagulation – at periphery of wound.

questions.text: Find the incorrect pair as per Jackson’s zones of tissue injury in burns:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zone of coagulation – at periphery of wound.

 

Option D:

 

Zone of coagulation is at the centre of the wound as per Jackson’s burn model.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Zone of Coagulation - Most Severely Burned Portion:

 

  • This central zone experiences the most severe injury, leading to irreversible damage and necrosis.
  • The tissues in this zone cannot be salvaged and typically undergo coagulative necrosis.

 

Option B. Zone of Hyperaemia - Heals with Minimal Scarring:

 

  • The outermost zone, characterized by increased blood flow and vasodilation.
  • Injuries in this zone have the potential to heal with minimal or no scarring, even without intervention.

 

Option C. Zone of Stasis - Variable Degree of Vasoconstriction:

 

  • Located between the zone of coagulation and hyperaemia.
  • Experiences vasoconstriction and ischemia to varying degrees.
  • Timely intervention can salvage tissues in this zone, preventing progression to irreversible damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the correct spatial arrangement of Jackson's zones in burn injuries, with the zone of coagulation positioned centrally, zone of stasis in between, and the zone of hyperemia as the outermost region.

 

  • Central zone- zone of coagulation-> cannot be salvaged.
  • Zone of stasis - variable degrees of vasoconstriction and ischemia-> can be salvaged with timely intervention.
  • Zone of hyperemia - outermost zone, heals with minimal or no scarring even without intervention.

 

Ref: Sabiston textbook of Surgery 20th edition pg 506

choices.text: 8 liters
4 liters
2 liters
6 liters

questions.text: A 50-kg adult man has suffered from 40% second degree burns. How much fluid will be needed for resuscitation in first 8 hours as per Parkland’s equation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 liters

 

Explanation

 

Fluid resuscitation in burns

 

 

As per Parkland formula total fluid to be given in a 50 kg man = 4 ml x 50kg x 40 %TBSA= 8 litres of this ½ is given in the first 8 hours so, 4 litres is given in the first 8 hours.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 671

choices.text: Silver nitrate
Silver sulphadiazine
Mafenide acetate
Cerium nitrate

questions.text: Which of these burns creams causes metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mafenide acetate

 

Option C:

 

Mafenide acetate is known to cause metabolic acidosis, especially when applied to extensive burns due to the release of carbon dioxide during its antimicrobial action.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Silver nitrate: It may cause skin discoloration but is not known for causing metabolic acidosis.

 

Option B. Silver sulphadiazine: Silver sulfadiazine is a commonly used burn cream that acts as a broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent with anti-pseudomonas actions. It does not cause metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Cerium nitrate: Cerium nitrate is not related to metabolic acidosis, however it helps in improving local cell mediated immunity.

 

Educational objective:

 

Mafenide acetate, when applied to extensive burns, can lead to metabolic acidosis due to the liberation of carbon dioxide during its antimicrobial action. This is popular, especially in the USA, but is painful to apply. It is usually used as a 5% topical solution.

 

  • Acticoat. This is a nanocrystalline silver barrier dressing and is an effective antimicrobial against a broad spectrum of bacteria.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 674

choices.text: Electrical burns
Partial thickness burns of 7% TBSA in an adult
Chemical burns
Inhalational injury

questions.text: Which of these burns’ patients would not require admission at a designated burns centre?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Partial thickness burns of 7% TBSA

 

Option B.

 

Partial thickness burns involving more than 10% TBSA are typically referred to designated burn centers for specialized care. Burns involving less than 10% TBSA may be managed at local facilities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Electrical burns: Electrical burns are referred to designated burn centers due to the potential for deep tissue injury and internal damage, which may not be evident initially.

 

Option C. Chemical burns: Chemical burns are referred to designated burn centers due to the potential for extensive tissue damage and complications.

 

Option D. Inhalational injury: Inhalational injuries, including burns affecting the airway, are referred to designated burn centers for specialized respiratory care.

 

Educational objective:

 

Partial thickness burns involving more than 10% TBSA warrant referral to a designated burn center for comprehensive management.

 

PATIENTS WITH THE FOLLOWING CRITERIA ARE REFERRED TO DESIGNATED BURN CENTER

 

  • Partial-thickness burns>10% TBSA
  • Burns involving the face, hands, feet, genitalia, perineum or major joints
  • Any full-thickness burn
  • Electrical burns, including lightning injury
  • Chemical burns
  • Inhalation injury
  • Burns in patients with preexisting medical disorders that could complicate management, prolong recovery, or affect outcome
  • Any patient with burns and concomitant trauma (e.g., fractures) in which the burn injury poses the greater immediate risk for morbidity and mortality
  • Burned children in hospitals without qualified personnel or equipment to care for children
  • Burns in patients who will require social, emotional, or long-term rehabilitative intervention   

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 666

choices.text: Irrigation of burns site
Topical application of calcium gluconate gel
Intra-arterial injection of calcium gluconate
Bier’s block

questions.text: A 45-year-old scientist while working in the laboratory accidentally pours chemical (hydrofluoric acid) over his right hand. What is the mainstay in management of this chemical burn?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical application of calcium gluconate gel

 

Option B:

 

Hydrofluoric acid burns, which chelate calcium, necessitate the topical application of calcium gluconate gel to counteract the effects of the acid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Irrigation of burn site: While irrigation is important for chemical burns, the specific nature of hydrofluoric acid burns requires additional measures beyond irrigation.

 

Option C. Intra-arterial injection of calcium gluconate: This option is not a standard or recommended method for managing hydrofluoric acid burns. Topical application is the primary approach.

 

Option D. Bier’s block: Bier's block may be considered for severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand, but it is not the mainstay of management.

 

Educational objective:

 

Understanding the specific management approach for hydrofluoric acid burns, which involves the topical application of calcium gluconate gel to counteract the chelating effects on calcium in tissues.

 

Management of chemical burns:

 

  • Damage is from corrosive acid poisoning
  • Copious lavage with water helps in most cases
  • In chemical powders, initially brush it off before washing

 

Management of hydrofluoric acid burns:

 

  • One acid that is a common cause of acid burns is hydrofluoric acid, although generally a weak acid, it chelates calcium and magnesium in tissues.
  • The initial management is with calcium gluconate gel topically; however, severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand can be subsequently treated with Bier’s blocks containing calcium gluconate 10% gel.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 680

choices.text: Dextrose Normal Saline
Human albumin
Ringer lactate
Normal saline

questions.text: As a part of resuscitation of patient with 40% total burns surface area (TBSA), what would be the fluid of choice in an adult in the first 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ringer lactate

 

Option C:

 

Ringer lactate: Hartmann’s solution or Ringer’s lactate is the most commonly used crystalloid as it closely replicates the osmolality of plasma and is cost-effective.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dextrose Normal Saline: While it provides glucose and saline, it may not be the fluid of choice for extensive resuscitation due to its composition.

 

Option B. Human albumin: Colloids like human albumin can be used but are expensive and may leak out of capillaries in the first 12 hours.

 

Option D. Normal saline: Normal saline can cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, making it less ideal for extensive resuscitation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hartmann’s solution or Ringer’s lactate is the most commonly used crystalloid as it most closely replicates the osmolality of plasma. It is considerably less expensive than colloid and can maintain intravascular volume.

 

Crystalloid resuscitation requires eight-fold greater volumes than colloid which can result in increased tissue oedema.

 

Normal saline - Causes hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis

 

Colloid - Can be used but is expensive and leaks out of capillaries in first 12 hours.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 671

choices.text: 9%
18%
27%
36%

questions.text: A 35-year-old housewife suffers from burns due to explosion of gas cylinder in the kitchen. Her both upper limbs are charred along with head, face and neck. Calculate the %TBSA:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 27%

 

Explanation

 

According to Wallace’s rule in an adult,

 

Each upper limb – 9% (total 18% for both upper limbs)

 

Head, face and neck -9%

 

Total burns area (%TBSA) = 27%

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 668

choices.text: Increased capillary permeability
Peripheral vasodilation
Decreased venous return
Decreased cardiac output

questions.text: Identify the cardiovascular system change that DOES NOT happen in a patient of burns:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peripheral vasodilation

 

Option B:

 

In burns patients, due to hypovolemia, peripheral vasoconstriction is usually seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased capillary permeability: Burns can lead to increased capillary permeability, causing fluid shift and edema.

 

Option C. Decreased venous return: Burns can lead to hypovolemia and decreased venous return to the heart.

 

Option D. Decreased cardiac output: Due to factors like hypovolemia and decreased venous return, cardiac output may decrease in burn patients.

 

Educational objective:

 

The cardiovascular changes in burn patients includes increased capillary permeability, decreased venous return, and potential decrease in cardiac output.

 

CVS changes in burns:

 

 

Overall changes in burns:

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 665-668

choices.text: Ringer lactate
5% dextrose
Normal saline
Dextrose saline

questions.text: In children with burns, maintenance IV fluid normally given is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dextrose saline.

 

Explanation:

 

In children with burns maintenance fluid preferred is dextrose - saline given as follows:

 

  • 100 mL/kg for 24 hours for the first 10 kg.
  • 50 mL/kg for the next 10 kg.
  • 20 mL/kg for 24 hours for each kilogram over 20 kg body weight.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 671

choices.text: Epidermis
Papillary dermis
Reticular dermis
Entire dermis

questions.text: Which layer is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial thickness burn?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Papillary dermis

 

Option B:

 

Blistering is typical of superficial partial thickness burns, where the damage in these burns goes no deeper than the papillary dermis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The underlying dermis is pink and moist and will exudate fluid for up to 36 hours post burn injury.
  • The capillary return is clearly visible when blanched.
  • There is little or no fixed capillary staining
  • Pinprick sensation is normal.
  • Superficial partial-thickness burns heal without residual scarring in 2 weeks
  • The treatment is supportive

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 669

choices.text: Burned nasal hair
Burns over face and neck
Burns while bathing
Stridor

questions.text: Which of these is not a feature of suspected inhalational injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Burns while bathing

 

Option C:

 

Burns while bathing: This is not a typical feature of suspected inhalational injury; burns during bathing are more likely related to scald injuries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Burned nasal hair: Singeing of facial and nasal hair is a warning sign of inhalational injury due to exposure to hot air or smoke.

 

Option B. Burns over face and neck: Burns in these areas are indicative of potential inhalational injury as the airway is exposed to harmful substances during a fire.

 

Option D. Stridor: Stridor, a high-pitched sound during breathing, is a warning sign of airway obstruction and inhalational injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

Warning signs of burns to the respiratory system:

 

  • Burns around the face and neck, blistering inside the mouth
  • A history of being trapped in an enclosed space
  • Change to/hoarseness of voice
  • Stridor
  • Singeing of facial and nasal hair

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 665

choices.text: 15%
25%
40%
50%

questions.text: Hypovolemic shock can occur if total burns surface area exceeds?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 15%

 

Explanation

 

The shock reaction after burns:

 

  • Burns produce an inflammatory reaction.
  • This leads to vastly increased vascular permeability.
  • Water, solutes, and proteins move from the intra- to the extravascular space.
  • The volume of fluid lost is directly proportional to the area of the burn.
  • Above 15% of surface area, the loss of fluid produces shock requiring resuscitation.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 665

choices.text: Leg
Thigh
Head
Arm

questions.text: As per Lund and Browder charts, which of these areas is not affected by age during calculation of %TBSA in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arm

 

Option D:

 

Arm: According to Lund and Browder charts, the arm is not affected by age during the calculation of %TBSA, and its percentage contribution remains constant across different age groups.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Lund and Browder charts adjust the percentage contribution of different body areas to total body surface area based on age, except for the arm where the percentage remains constant.

 

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 668
